name: Nahal Bezek (Wadi el-Beir)
type: Wadi / Water Source / Military Waypoint / Ambush Location
coordinates: Approximately 15–18 miles north of Jerusalem; Lat 32.32, Long 35.40
historical_status: Real historical location; critical waypoint for armies, merchant caravans, and travelers moving north from Judea; natural boundary and barrier since antiquity
narrative_significance: A critical waypoint on the primary trade and military route toward Samaria. The wadi's spring (Ein Bezek) provides the only reliable water for miles, forcing Roman cohorts and caravans into a narrow, vulnerable passage. The extended hydration period (90+ minutes for a full cohort) makes it ideal for coordinated ambush—a landscape where water means both survival and danger.
story_arcs: Military route; ambush-vulnerable water stop; caravan route; pivotal in Roman march sequences
one_line_description: A limestone wadi north of Jerusalem where the spring of Ein Bezek draws travelers into a narrow, ambush-vulnerable passage—water as both survival and trap.

physical_description.title: Physical Description & Layout
physical_description.geographic_setting: Approximately 15–18 miles north of Jerusalem along the primary trade and military route toward Samaria. The wadi cuts through the landscape like a scar carved by ancient waters, creating a north-south passage through elevated terrain. Steep limestone banks rise 15–25 feet on both eastern and western sides. The wadi channel runs dry most of the year; in winter, after rare heavy rains, water rushes through with violent force. Sparse shrubs and stunted trees dot the ridge above.
physical_description.scale: Wadi passage narrow enough to concentrate travelers at the spring. Spring pool approximately 12 feet wide and 4–6 feet deep. Natural alcoves and formations on both banks; western bank 20–30 feet above wadi level provides elevated ambush positions. Small caves and recessed areas deep enough to conceal 3–4 people.
physical_description.natural_features: Limestone canyon with weathered cream, tan, and pale gray stone; natural alcoves and formations; Ein Bezek spring emerging from a fissure in the eastern bank; year-round spring flow sufficient to water a hundred soldiers and animals; packed earth and scattered loose stones in dry channel.
physical_description.primary_structures: Ein Bezek (Spring of Bezek)—natural pool, limestone basin worn smooth by centuries of use; no built structures; natural rock formations and alcoves serve as concealment and vantage points.

sensory_details.title: Sensory Details & Atmosphere
sensory_details.overall_impression: Arid, stark, vulnerable. Golden-hour light creates dramatic amber illumination; at midday, shadows fall deep and sharp. In summer: extreme heat, dust clouds, parched landscape. In winter: darker wet stone, richer greens, flowing water. The spring stands out as an island of clear blue-green water in an otherwise dry landscape.
sensory_details.dominant_colors: Cream, tan, and pale gray limestone; warm amber in angled light; deep brown and gray shadows; pale gray dust in summer; moss and algae green-gold at the spring; clear blue-green water.
sensory_details.signature_visual: Steep limestone banks rising on both sides; the spring pool as oasis; golden-hour light penetrating the wadi; natural alcoves and rock formations; dust rising from the passage in dry season.
sensory_details.lighting: Golden-hour light at morning and evening creates dramatic amber illumination. At midday, deep sharp shadows where high banks create shelter. Stone glows with warm tones. At night, deep shadow; torch or lamp creates pools of golden light that emphasize the darkness.
sensory_details.essential_atmosphere: Water as survival and trap. The extended vulnerable period—90+ minutes for a cohort to hydrate—makes the passage feel both intimate and isolating. Starkness in summer; abundance and threat coexisting in winter.

historical_context.title: Historical & Cultural Context
historical_context.historical_significance: Critical waypoint since antiquity. Served as natural boundary and barrier. Primary route for armies, merchant caravans, and travelers moving north from Judea toward Samaria. Two-day march from Jerusalem (30–35 miles total).
historical_context.cultural_importance: Water source on an otherwise waterless route. Strategic chokepoint where all northbound traffic must pass. Natural ambush site due to extended hydration requirements.
historical_context.symbolic_meaning: The landscape forces vulnerability—thirst draws travelers into the open, where the narrow passage and elevated banks create ideal ambush conditions. Water brings both life and danger.

primary.name: Roman cohorts
primary.role: March north from Jerusalem; forced to stop at spring; vulnerable during 90+ minute hydration period

primary.name: Merchant caravans
primary.role: Use same route; depend on Ein Bezek for water; targets of ambush

primary.name: Ambushers
primary.role: Concealed in natural alcoves and rock formations; elevated positions on western bank overlook spring

key_scenes.title: Key Scenes & Events
events: Two-day march from Jerusalem: Day 1—cohort camps near olive groves; Day 2—arrives at Nahal Bezek by late afternoon
Water management: 45–90 minutes for full cohort hydration; additional 30–45 minutes for supply train animals; minimum 90 minutes vulnerable period
Ambush vulnerability: Natural alcoves and western bank positions allow observation and attack on soldiers at the spring
Seasonal transformation: Summer—dry channel, dust, desperation; Winter—flowing water, treacherous passage, brief lush growth
